NS-Atomic

Overview

NS-Atomic is a centralized framework and guide that defines the common styles and conventions shared across NuSkin's web products. This page provides a brief overview of what is available, but you should review the actual stylesheets to see everything.

Atomic Design

NS-Atomic is partially based on Brad Frost's Atomic Design principles. Namely it is based on the idea that instead of solely designing a page and trying to figure out how to style the page to fit elements together, we instead build and design components which are reactive and put them together to build pages. If you are unfamiliar with the concept, you should take some time to read up on it.

Features

Most, if not all, components are reactive and adaptive, meaning that they will respond to the size of screen. Many components will also change behavior based on surrounding elements. This is not an exhaustive list of features, but lists some of the key things available:

  • Standardized colors and layers
  • Typography
  • Button Styling and states
  • Sizing and layout shortcuts
  • Compound elements
  • Dropdowns and inputs
  • Shadows
  • Zurb Grid
  • Modals (fully responsive!)

This page is currently static, so anything added after March 31, 2015 won't show up automatically. This page will be made dynamic later on.

Getting Started

NS-Atomic should have a stylesheet ready-built sitting under global.css. Simply include this file in your project, and you'll have the styles ready to go. NOTICE: This process may change soon.

If you need to use a different brand color, or need make other changes to the atomic styles, you will need to create your a new folder under sites. For instance: sites/my-app. It is recommended that you copy the nuskin site folder as a base and then make changes from there.

Conventions

Semantic Vocabulary

NS-Atomic follows a very modular pattern for its styling, offering a lot of rules and styles that you can "mix-and-match". The goal is to provide the markup developer with a powerful "vocabulary" which they can use to describe how the elements should look and behave while minimizing the amount of work that needs to be done. The Semantic vocabulary is the use of classes, ids, attributes, and tag names in order to make descriptiv and impactful markup.

Whenever it makes sense, use naming and conventions which reflect usage and application, even if it means simple assigning another variable to it. Consider the following example: 

            $color-error: 				   #C71013;
            $color-warning: 			           $color-error;
            $color-delete: 				   $color-error;

Currently we use the same color for warning and delete, but we still define them separately so instead of just using "$color-red" or "$color-red-dark", which only have meaning implicitly, we define what the color is actually used for.

When creating new markup and styling, consider whether or not sensible vocabulary could be made to describe what you are doing.

Markup

Whenever possible, you should opt to use existing vocubalary with, or instead of, new vocabulary. For example, If you are making a component which will only ever consist of a single button and input field, there's no need to create a new class for each of those. Simply create a class or id for the parent and reference the child elements by tag name. 

            .input-with-button {
              input { ... }
              button { ... }
            }

Consider the situation where you might want a particular element to have larger text. Do all elements of this kind need to have larger text, or just this one instance? Rather than creating custom sizing for that one element, use

Never sacrifice understandable code in favor of terseness. If vocubulary or rules do not have strongly imply the relationship of parts, make sure the naming conventions are specific enough to ensure they are. Consider the following example: 

            .modal {
              &> div:first-child { ... }
              &> div:nth-child(2) { ... }
              &> div:last-child { ... }
            }
Not only is the code example highly brittle, but it also is too generic and reads poorly. Opt instead to utilize existing vocabulary, specifically tag names, where it makes sense.

Naming

Names should be descriptive and should use dashes to seperate words, not camelCase. Names should be descriptive without being overly verbose. 

.some-class {
              value: $my-variable;
          }

As an example, take a look at the rule for small buttons in _buttons.sizes.scss


            &.size-sm {
              @extend .font-xs;
              min-height:$button-height-sm;
              padding-left:7px;
              padding-right:7px;

              @include phone-button-height($phone-tap-height - 10);
            }

Variable names should include category to make it easier to find them later and to clarify variable type and usage. All global colors are prefixed with $color. 

            $color-primary: 			   #008ab0;

Rule Order & Nesting

To help with readability and consistency keep the following order when writing your scss:

  1. @extends
  2. @includes
  3. Properties
  4. States/Variants ('&' rules)
  5. Nested elements

In this way, someone who is reading your code can easily determine what the styling is of the element itself without having to scan the entire rule.

To limit complexity, it may be useful sometimes to break up your rule into parts for readability. As rules get longer they become difficult to keep track of.

Absolute Placeholders

A placeholder that takes up space to allow an element to still be "part of" a container (e.g. affect its size) while also positioning the element releative to the container.

Some Container

Some text that follows the container. If this is working as it should, then the button should be inside the above container and not overlapping any other elements.

Grid

NS Atomic uses Zurb Foundation's Grid framework. In order to prevent some of the broader styling from bleeding out into other parts of the code, all of Zurb's functionality is scoped within the .grid class. So any time you want to utilize the grid it must be applied either to the row element, or to an ancestor.

Anchor To

Customization

NS-Atomic is highly customizable, allowing you to customize everything from the fonts and colors to mobile breakpoints and button styling. These thigns can all be changed without modifying any of core files.

How to Customize

There are two ways to customize. The preferred way to customize is to change variable values in sites/my-app/config.scss. You can see all the global variables in default-config.scss.

If you need to make larger changes or overrides that apply only to your app, you will need to make the changes in your overrides.scss file. Use discretion when overriding the global styles.

Compilation

When you create your own variant of the atomic styles, you will need to run the compilation yourself. This can be done with Compass, but may have a smoother process in the future.

Changing Colors

Most of the basic colors can be overriden. More colors will be added in the future. NS-Atomic simplifies things for you by computing variants automatically from base colors. If you want to change the primary (brand) color, for example, its as easy as this: 

            $color-primary: green;

Scoping NS-Atomic

The global styles can be scoped using the .ns-atomic class, so only items with an ancestor of '.ns-atomic' will actually have the styles applied. Scoping is currently being used in the AEM project to aid the transition to using global styles and prevent the styles from affecting areas until we're ready to apply them. 

          $global-use-namespace: true;

Typically you should just apply ns-atomic to your body tag, unless you have a good reason for wanting to limit the global styles on a particular page.
